supporting_text: The NAP outlines five strategic priorities which are well aligned with Global AMR Action Plan, addressing human, animal, and environmental health.
The NAP mentions specific actions in the human health sector, including improving awareness and understanding of AMR through effective communication, education, and training.
The NAP includes strategies to optimize the use of antimicrobial agents in animal health and regulate access to high-quality antimicrobial agents.
The NAP addresses environmental health by including strategies to reduce environmental contamination with antimicrobial residues and resistant pathogens.
The NAP includes actions related to the use of antimicrobials in agriculture and food security, particularly in the context of animal health.
An M&E framework has been developed, with indicators for input/process, output, and outcome for each focus area.
The NAP outlines specific targets, such as a 50% increase in awareness of AMR among the general population by 2026.
The NAP includes targets for surveillance of antimicrobial consumption and aims for a 60% consumption of antibiotics from the Access group.
The document does not specify budget allocations for the strategies or actions.
The document does not contain an assessment of future budget requirements.
A National Multisectoral Committee has been established to coordinate AMR activities across different sectors.
The NAP includes strategies to develop regulations and policies for the appropriate use of antimicrobials.
The NAP outlines strategies to improve education and training on AMR for various professional groups.
The NAP includes actions to improve awareness and understanding of AMR through effective communication and public awareness campaigns.
The NAP emphasizes the importance of international collaboration and partnerships with organizations like WHO, FAO, and OIE.
The NAP includes strategies for strengthening laboratory capacity and establishing surveillance systems for AMR.
The NAP outlines the need for capacity building to detect and report emerging resistance.
The NAP includes strategies to reduce the incidence of infection through effective sanitation, hygiene, and infection prevention measures.
The NAP aligns with international standards and guidelines for AMR control.
The NAP includes strategies to regulate the distribution and prescription of antibiotics.
The NAP includes regulations to ensure the rational use of antibiotics.
The NAP emphasizes the need for collaboration in research to develop new medicines and diagnostic tools.
